newsitem.title: UK: British firm bids $2.1 billion for Chubb Security.
newsitem.headline: British firm bids $2.1 billion for Chubb Security.

text.p: Britain's Williams Holdings Plc on Friday launched a 1.3 billion-pound ($2.12 billion) offer for Chubb Security Plc in a deal that would unite global home and security brand names like Yale locks and Chubb safes.
"From an industrial point of view, it is an absolutely logical fit," Williams Chief Executive Roger Carr said in an interview.

Williams' brands include Yale locks and security devices and Kidde, a maker of fire protection products which is the leading U.S. supplier of domestic fire extinguishers. Williams also owns Corbin Russwin locks and door-closing devices in North America.
Chubb makes locks, safes, fire extinguishers and alarms and provides security guards. It is not affiliated with Chubb Corp., the Warren, N.J.-based insurance company.
A merger would create a company with combined annual sales of about 2.7 billion pounds ($4.46 billion).

Williams said its strengths in the Americas and Continental Europe would get a boost from Chubb's presence in Britain and the Asia-Pacific region. The deal also would unlock benefits in purchasing, distribution and plant consolidation.
Analysts agreed the merger made good strategic sense, but some balked at the cash-and-stock offer, which valued Chubb at 450 pence ($7.34) per share.
"The fit is excellent for Williams, but the issue is the price. People think they overpaid. They should have paid maybe 15-16 times earnings, not 21 times," one analyst said.

"It is the price they had to pay to improve the quality of Williams. They will make it pay, but it will take a little longer than perhaps we would have preferred," said Geoff Allum, diversified industrials analyst at Henderson Crosthwaite.
Williams and Chubb were among the most heavily traded stocks on the London Stock Exchange.

Williams dropped 37 pence (60 cents), or nearly 11 percent, to 301 pence ($4.91), making it one of the biggest percentage losers on the exchange, while Chubb dropped 52 pence (85 cents) to 368 pence ($6.00).
Williams said its offer represented a 37 percent premium over the closing price of 329.5 pence ($5.38) for Chubb stock Tuesday.
Takeover speculation since then has pushed Chubb stock higher in a surge that was being investigated by the London Stock Exchange.
On Thursday, Chubb's stock soared 82 pence ($1.34) or more than 24 percent, to a year high of 423 pence ($6.90) after the company said it was in talks that might lead to an offer for the company.
Williams's offer -- two new Williams shares and 704.12 pence ($11.49) in cash for every three Chubb shares -- consisted of about 50 percent cash and 50 percent stock, the company said.
Williams said it expected to receive regulatory clearance for the deal and overcome any possible monopoly concerns.
